A travesty.  Huh.  That's interesting,  because I think you did it.

Mr. M., I am running on my  qualifications.  I would never need to  resort to, you know, to vandalism like  a, you know... Plus, my own best banner  was torn down.  Did I do that too?

6:30.  How do you know what time the  posters were torn down?

I don't.  I just know they were there  when I left.  I'm giving you helpful  information is all.  You know, instead  of wasting time interrogating me, we  should be out there trying to find out  who did this.
Okay, Tracy, so who do you think did  it?  Whom should we "interrogate?"

well, I don't know.  It could have been  anybody.  There are a lot of, you know,  subversive elements around Millard.  You  know, like Rick Thieson and Kevin Speck  and those burn-outs.  Or Doug Schenken - what about him?  Or what about Tammy Metzier?  Her whole thing is being anti- this and anti-that.
JIM shifts gears

You're a very intelligent girl, Tracy.   You have many admirable qualities.  But  someday maybe you'll learn that being  smart and always being on top and doing  whatever you need to do to get ahead,  and yes, stepping on people to get  there, well, there's a lot more to life  than that.  And in the end, you're only  cheating yourself.
Why are you lecturing me?

This isn't the time or the place to get  into it, but there is, for just one  example, a certain former colleague of  mine, who made a very big mistake, a  life mistake.  I think the lesson there  is that, old and young, we ail make  mistakes, and we have to learn that our  actions, all of them, can carry serious  consequences.  You're very young, Tracy  underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.
I don't know what you're referring to,  but I do know that if certain older and  wiser people hadn't acted like such  little babies and gotten all mushy,  everything would be okay.

I agree.  But I also think certain  young and naive people need to thank  their lucky stars and be very, very  grateful the whole school didn't find  out about certain indiscretions which  could have ruined their reputations, and  chances to win certain elections.

And I think certain older persons like  you and your "colleague" shouldn't be  leaching after their students,  especially when some of them can't even  get their own wives pregnant.  And they  certainly shouldn't be running around  making slanderous accusations.   Especially when certain young, naive  people's mothers are para-legal  secretaries at the city's biggest law  firm and have won many successful  lawsuits. And if you want to keep  questioning me like this, I won't  continue without my attorney present.
JIM draws a long breath as he tries to control himself

As I walked out of my home that  evening, unsure if I'd ever return, my  entire life in question, I somehow  discovered within myself a place of  perfect peace.   Oddly, in my solitude I  felt more than ever a sense of communion  with every human being - past, present  and future.  Because no matter what we  tell ourselves, no matter what illusions  of friendship and family we create, each  of us is always and forever profoundly  alone.
FROM OVERHEAD - Tracy slides out of her bed and kneels be

Dear Lord Jesus, I do not often speak  with You and ask for things, but now I  really must insist that You help me win  the election tomorrow, because I deserve  it and Paul Metzier doesn't, as You well  know.  l realize that it was Your divine  hand that disqualified Tammy, and now  I'm asking that You go that one last  mile and make sure to put me in office  where I belong, so that I may carry out  Your will on Earth as it is in Heaven.   If elected I promise that I will pray  more often.  Okay?  Amen.
Tammy wears a white t-shirt and underwear and kneels at h

Dear God, I know I don't believe in  you, but since I'll be starting Catholic  school soon, I thought I should  practice.  Let's see... what do I want?   I want people to be nicer to each other.   I want Lisa to realize what a bitch she  has been and feel really bad and  apologize for how she hurt me and know  how much I still love her.  In spite of  everything, I still want Paul to win the  election tomorrow, not that cunt Tracy.   I also want a really expensive pair of  leather pants... and someday I want to  be really good friends with Madonna.   Love, Tammy
FROM OVERHEAD -- Paul lies in bed looking at the heavens ceiling,

Dear God, thank You for all Your  blessings.  You have given me so many  things, like good health, nice parents,  a nice truck, and what I've been told is  a large penis, and I'm very grateful.   But I sure am worried about Tammy.  In  my heart I still can't believe she tore  down my posters, but sometimes she does  get so weird and angry.  Please help her  be a happier person, because she's so  smart and sensitive, and I love her.   Also, I'm nervous about the election  tomorrow, and I guess I want to win and  all, but I know that's totally up to  You.  You'll decide who the best person  is, and I'll accept it.  And forgive my  sins, whatever they may be.  Amen.

head_text.subj: INT. TV AND MILLARD CLASSROOMS DAY

text: CLOSE ON A TV-- mounted in the corner.  An educational vi beginning.  Host CLARK NAYLOR sits on the edge of a desk office set. During the video, we cut to CLASSROOMS, where from the TV view, we see the students watching:  English class shop c class, biology class.

Hello, students,  I'm Clark Naylor of  Joslyn's Educational Resources.  It's  election day, and how you vote will make  a big difference in the activities,  events, and perhaps even the policies of  your school.  Over the past few days or  weeks, you've heard candidates for the  various offices make their speeches and  tell you where they stand.  You've  probably seen their posters.  Maybe  you've even had a chance to speak with  them personally.
Now replace the wider shots of classrooms.  Photographed from a Soviet propaganda film, some students look up nobl attentively, while others watch with dead eyes and open m still others goof off.

Well, today marks the end of  campaigning, and now the spotlight turns  to you. Voting is your privilege and  your responsibility. Remember, no one  needs to know for whom you've voted.   That's between you. . . and you.
An AFRICAN-AMERICAN TEENAGER walks up to Clark.
Now I'd like to introduce you to Tony.  Tony's going to show you how to cast  your vote.  Are you ready, Tony?
I think s0
Good.  Let's get started
JIM slinks down the hall and ducks into a PHONE BOOTH. He change out of his pocket and dials.   We hear the echo of emanating from all the classrooms.
Hi.  You've reached the Novotnys. We're  not around, but we'll call you back real  soon.  Have a nice day.

Are you there?  Sherry, are you there?   It's Jim.  (suddenly angry) Why did you do that?  I trusted you.  Completely.  You've ruined my life. Do  you know that?  Do you realize that?   Huh?  Do you?  You've ruined Diane's  life.  You ruined my life.  is that what  you wanted?  (recovering) I'm sorry.  It's just... I'm going nuts  here.  Okay, all right, so... Really,  I'm sorry.  I just think we should talk,  okay?  I love you.
JIM crosses out more ballots, this time with perverse int
If only my own life could be corrected  so easily, with nice fat black lines  drawn neatly through my sins.
as it is blackened.  We WIPE with the motion of the magic

head_text.subj: INT. LITTLE SALLY ANN SHOP DAY

text: The curtain of the dressing room is drawn back, and there beams and walks toward --
where she takes herself in, dressed in her new Catholic s UNIFORM. The SALESLADY converses nearby with Jo Metzier.
And Sacred Heart is such a good school.  Excellent school. The public schools are  going downhill, as far as I'm concerned.
Well, we've had good luck at Millard,  but for this one it's time for a change.
Tammy spins and admires the flip of the skirt.
So what do you think?  Sacred Heart has  the prettiest.  They have that nice hint  of purple.
(lying)  I hate it.
You're just going to have to get used  to it.
Please, morn.  Please don't make me go  to Sacred Heart.  I beg you.
(to saleslady) We'll take two.
Makeshift POLLING BOOTHS are set up just outside the cafe two tables sit TWO TEACHERS who cross out voters' names o computer lists. Tracy stands in line, not-so-patiently wa turn.
When the time came to cast our votes, I  stood in line just like everyone else.
She finally reaches the front of the line.
Hi, Tracy
Tracy Enid Flick.
I know.
Tracy goes into a VOTING BOOTH and quickly hands her ball PHIL CHOY stands nearby with his CAMERA.
Phil you ready?
Ready.
Tracy exits the booth and heads toward the BALLOT BOX.  S her ballot halfway and freezes, smiling.  Phil snaps a pi
Just a second.  My flash.
Tracy remains perfectly still while Phil fiddles with his STUDENT stands behind her, waiting to put his ballot in t
Come on, Tracy.
(through her smile)  Just wait.
FLASH!  Phil gets his shot and Tracy drops her ballot in.
Thanks, Phil.
On her way out Tracy passes Paul at the end of the line. an enthusiastic THUMBS UP.
Way to go, Tracy!  Isn't this exciting?
(awkward)  Yeah.
Hell, good luck!
(reluctant) Good luck to you too, Paul.
Thanks!
INT. VOTING BOOTH Paul scans his ballot, struggles with h
It's so weird.  DO people always just  vote for themselves?  'Cause looking at  my own name on the ballot, I just... I  don't know, I just felt like it's not  right to vote for yourself.
THE BALLOT - as Paul's pen puts an "X" next to the name "
THE BALLOT BOX is being carried through the halls and up by Larry Fouch and three other STUDENT COUNCIL MEMBERS. T suggests the weighty importance of its contents and the s of its bearers.
JIM is hunkered over his desk.  He's a wreck: dark, dark his eyes;  his hair didn't dry right -- frizzy here, matt And he's near tears. Larry Fouch and his retinue enter cheerfully
Okay, Mr. M.
Larry drops the ballot box on Jim's desk
What?  Right.  So let's start counting.
Well, I thought that... well, the way  it always works is that SGA president  does a count, then the SGA advisor, you  know, for the two independent counts.
Fine.  So do your count.  Start with  president, and I'll be right back.
You have the key, Mr. McAllister.
JIM doesn't understand at first, then
Right.  I know.
JIM proceeds to sort through his cluttered desk drawers b to find the key.  The council members exchange concerned Jim's search becomes frenzied.
Are you okay, Mr. M.?
What happened to your eye?
I'm fine.  It's just a bee sting, a  simple little everyday bee sting. Some  people, they get stung, it's no big  deal.  Me, I swell up.  Okay?
JIM emerges from the drawer wielding a VISE GRIP.  He goe and TEARS the entire hardware assembly off.  Holding the he turns to the students, who look back STUNNED.
I just want to get this over with, so  we can have the assembly and go home.   We don't have much time until eighth  period.  I have other things going on,  too, you know.
Okay.  Yeah.  We know
All right.  I'll be back

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE SCHOOL OFFICE DAY

text: JIM slinks up to a PAY PHONE, inserts a coin, dials
(cheery) Hi.  You've reached the Novotnys. We're  not around, but we'll call you back real  soon.  Have a nice day.
JIM it's me again.  I'm sorry for all the calls.  But She could just hear your voice, if you'd only acknowledge tha
(picking up phone)  What do you want, Jim?
You're there.
Yeah.  I'm here.
Sherry... I love you.
(loud exhale) Don't say that.  You know it's not  true.
It's the only true thing I know  anymore.
We made a mistake.  Let's not make it  worse.
A mistake?  That was no mistake.
I was lonely.  You took advantage
Me?  I took advantage of you?  You  hugged me!  You kissed me!  You're the  one who --
It's PASSING PERIOD, and the halls are jammed with studen lockers and walking to class. JIM is walking quickly back to his classroom. He passes P
Hey, Mr. M. Big day, huh?
Jim doesn't even hear.
Larry is  just finishing his count. The ballots are on a of  him, neatly organized into three piles. JIM enters.
(impatient) What d'you got?
I'm not supposed to tell. Not until  you've counted too. We're each supposed  to make an independent count.
You're kidding, right?
I thought those were the rules, Mr.  McAllister. If they've changed in any  way --
Larry, we're not electing the fucking  Pope here. Just tell me who won.
Jim's use of profanity scares Larry, and he responds relu
It's a squeaker, Mr. M. I've got Tracy  by a vote. Just one vote.
Jim, who hasn't cared about any of this today, suddenly t stares blankly at Larry as the news sinks in.
Mr. M.?
Huh.  Okay.  Well, I guess I'd better  do my count.
Jim-scoops up the three piles of ballots and takes them t
a junior honors student. He is thinking. The wheels are t grinding. Finally --
Sputnik.
MR. FLAGG is lecturing, really trying to make history com Tracy takes notes, but she is noticeably distracted.
Right.  And what year was that?

Almost.  1957.  So the point here is  when we found out about Sputnik, we got  really scared.  It seemed like no matter  what we had and kept secret, they could  develop it too.  A-bombs, h-bombs,  rocket ships.  And this time we were  behind them.  So -- February 1961,  Kennedy tells Congress and the American  people he wants to go to the moon.  May  1961, the Apollo program is announced...
Tracy just can't take it anymore.  She abruptly stands up GIANT HALL PASS off the lip of the blackboard, and starts Mr. Flagg gives her a small nod.

Tracy nears a room, a special room.  She slows down and p window of the door.  She sees -- LARRY FOUCH  sitting at the back of the classroom, starin Tracy presses her face to see what Larry is staring at -- JIM at his desk counting ballots LARRY catches sight of Tracy in the window. TRACY crosses her fingers by her ears and gives a questio LARRY sneaks a guilty look at Jim, absorbed in his counti against his better judgment flashes Tracy a quick, furtiv THUMBS-UP. TRACY suddenly disappears from the window. IN THE EMPTY HALLWAY - Tracy pogos with unbridled joy

You know that moment when they announce  the winner of a beauty pageant?  When  Miss Texas or whoever suddenly realizes  she's Miss America, and all she can do  is scream and weep and hug the losers?   I had my moment in the hallway that  Tuesday afternoon with no one to hug but  myself.
She pulls herself together enough to peek through the win OTHER DOOR to Jim's classroom, the window behind which JI is still busily doing his count.
JIM counts out the last of the ballots, mouthing the numb himself.

I was at the end of my count when it  happened.  I'd come up with exactly the  same numbers as Larry:  Tracy had won  the election by a single vote, 256 to  257.  I was about to announce my tally  when...
JIM looks up and sees TRACY in the window, her face exploding with joy.  She FR We move closer to Jim in SLOW-MOTION.  What actually occu split-second is suspended in time

The sight of Tracy at that moment  affected me in a way I can't fully  explain.  Part of it was that she was  spying, but mostly it was her face.  Looking at her, you might think she was  a sweet, innocent teenage girl. But she  wasn't sweet.  And she wasn't innocent.  She was selfish and cynical and  ambitious and thought nothing of  destroying the lives of others to get to  the top. who knew how high she would  climb in life, how many people would  suffer because of her? I had to stop her  now.
Tracy UNFREEZES and darts out of sight. JIM glances at La writing in a notebook.

creeps up from his lap and onto the pile of TRACY VOTES. nimbly count two ballots and pull them off the desk. JIM coughs as beneath his desk he CRUMPLES THE BALLOTS in drops them into the wastepaper basket.
Larry?
(looking up)  Yeah?
I think we've got a problem.
Walt is just finishing counting the ballots on his desk. stand over him.
253... 254... 255. I get the same as  you Jim. Looks like Paul's our  president.
No way I It doesn't make sense.
Sorry. My figures work out exactly the  same as Jim's. 256 for Paul, 255 for  Tracy.
And 290 "disregards," right?
If you say so.
Mostly Tammy fans
See, it doesn't add up. There are only  801 ballots but 803 people voted. Two  votes are missing. Check the register.
He's right. Two people must have  pocketed their ballots. Usually it's  more.
But, they were there I counted 803  votes.
It happens, Larry. People make  mistakes.
I didn't make a mistake. Every vote was  there when you sac down
Whoa! Easy, Fouch. I don't like where  you're going.
I'm telling you. Dr. Hendricks, every  vote was accounted for.

(stern) Larry? We've got twenty-five minutes  until the assembly, and we still have to  do counts for VP, Treasurer and  Secretary. Mr. Hendricks and I have both  verified the numbers, and unless you can  come up with the ballots you claim are  missing -
But, Mr. M. -
Fouch, that's enough! End of story.
AN ASSEMBLY - The students are taking their seats on the

are all the candidates:  three for secretary, two for tre for vice-president, two for president. PAUL AND TRACY sit side-by-side.  Paul seems a little ove the whole thing.  Tracy leans over and offers her hand.
Paul, I just want you to know that no  matter how this turns out, you've run a  wonderful campaign. It's been fun  competing with you.
Yeah, you too, Tracy.  I'm just glad  it's over.
Yeah.
You know, I don't understand why  everybody bad-mouthed Tracy all the  time.  She was always super- nice to me.
JIM approaches the microphone
If we could get started.  People! Once  the winners are announced, we can all go  home, okay?
The students quiet down

Some contests are so well fought that  is seems unfair for someone to win and  someone to lose.  I think that's the  case with all the candidates you see  before you today.  All of them are  highly qualified and embody the, uh, the  integrity we expect from our school  leadership.
OS TRACY - Jim's voice momentarily recedes.
Act surprised. Walk slowly to the  podium.  Be modest.  Thank them for this  incredible honor.
That said, the whole point of an  election is to choose winners, and that  you have done.  We'll begin with  president.
JIM pulls a folded paper from his back pocket
Let me add that this was an  extraordinarily close race. It's my  pleasure to announce the next president  of Millard High School.
Tracy just can't wait.  Smiling, she STANDS UP.
Paul Metzier!

The crowd breaks into applause -- and laughter ON TRACY - AS she sits, her smile belies her horror and h Paul begins his acceptance speech.  We cut alternately to Lisa; a stunned Tracy, tears forming at the corners of he to JIM, who watches the events with shifty eyes, his mout tasting of metal.

Geez, you guys, thanks a lot.  I mean,  wow, thanks.  I promise to do my best  and really do a good job and be a good  president.  And I want to thank Lisa  Flanagan for being a super campaign  manager. And I just want to say that I  think Tracy would have made a great  president too and that she really  deserves a big hand.
The auditorium erupts into applause and whistles, and JIM microphone again.
And now, for vice-president.
In the growing darkness, the restaurant radiates its dist orange glow. The parking lot is nearly empty.
JIM sits alone at a booth by the window, finishing    a s pie. He gets the attention of a WAITRESS and holds up his
Could I get a...?
As JIM gets his warm-up, in walk the Metziers: Paul,  Dic notices them as they wait to be seated. He    wishes he w invisible. As a PERKY HOSTESS leads the family to a table, Paul  spo it comes.
Wow! Mr. McAllister! This is so wild.  We came to celebrate my victory, and I  can't believe it. Here, these are my  parents.
JIM stands up awkwardly.
(extending his  hand)  Hi. Dick Metzier. My wife --
This is great.
(extending his  hand) JIM McAllister.
(extending her  hand) JO Metzier. You know, Paul just thinks  the world of you. Oh, if you could just  hear him...
Yeah, say, apparently you've really  come behind him, really helped him out  there with the student council thing and  all.
I never would have ran if it wasn't for  Mr. M.
Paul doesn't need any of my help. He's  going places.  You should be very proud.
We are
Having a problem with your eye there?
Dick.
Just a bee sting.
You ought to get that looked at. Shot  of cortisone or something.
Thanks, I'll be fine.
Anyway, we're awful sorry about what  went on with our other one, you know,  our Tammy.
We were mortified...
Oh, she's not a bad girl.  She'll come  around.
... but we've had some good talks, and  I think we're sorting things out.  We're  starting her at Sacred Heart in the  fall.
Good school.
Say, you're all alone,  why don't you  join us?
Yeah!
Oh, no.  No.  I'm just finishing up  here, and I've got to get home.
(to his parents) Why don't you guys go sit down, okay?   I'll catch up in a minute? I want to  talk to Mr. M. about some important  stuff.
All right.  Well, sure nice to meet  you.
So nice
You bet.
The Metziers go, and- Paul slides in across from Jim.
So, Mr. M,  I was starting to think  about ideas for next year. I was  thinking it would be cool to have, like  a carnival.  With rides.  And, you know,  it could be for, like. Muscular  Dystrophy.
JIM tries to smile and seem attentive, but we sense his p fatigue and his profound sadness.

And on Halloween we could have a  haunted house.  But a really good  haunted house, not like those cheesy bad  ones.  You know, more like the radio  station ones.  This one would be really  scary.  And for Homecoming -- well, you  know how last year's theme was -
Paul... Paul.... We'll have plenty of  time to get into all this later.  A  whole year, in fact. Right now I just  need to finish my pie and get home.
Oh, okay.  Yeah, sorry.
The wind out of his sails, Paul gets up and is about to g
Just one more thing.  So, Mr. M., uh,  do you think Tracy's going to be okay?   I saw her face after the assembly, and I  think she's taking it pretty hard.
Don't worry about Tracy.  She'll be  fine.
her face drained and pallid, her eyes red and bleary: she from crying.
One vote... one vote

She falls again headlong again into the throes of despair contorts into a rictus of agony, and there issues an almo of pain. Her anguish grows convulsive. Barbara Flick comes in and sits on the bed. She's carryin PRESCRIPTION BOTTLE and a glass of milk.
Why don't you take a couple of my  pills, darling? You'll feel better.
Tracy takes the pills and sips the milk weakly. Her mothe
Don ' t worry. .. don ' t worry. . .  sshhhhh... that's it, baby... that's it,  darling. Everything's going to be fine.
She lays Tracy on the bed, and Tracy begins to quiet. Bar her again and rises to leave. At  the door she pauses to final words of comfort.
Maybe you needed more posters, honey.  Or if you'd taken my suggestions about  your speech. I don't know. We'll figure  it out.
JIM stands at his own back door, beaten and ashamed.  He and knocks.  After a moment the door opens, and there is
Diane, I...

Diane looks at JIM in silence.  Her face reveals nothing, a deadness in her eyes.  After a moment, she turns back i leaving the door open. JIM follows his wife inside, closes the door.  The camera peek in the kitchen window, from where we watch JIM and D cannot make out anything they say.

I don't know how Diane and I made it  through that night, but we did.  Our  marriage had gone right to the brink,  but in the end I guess it was saved by  one simple fact: we truly loved each  other.  So we made a commitment to begin  the painful process of piecing our lives  back together.  The worst was over; the  mistakes of the past were behind us.

A WASTE BASKET peeks out from under Jim's desk. We hear a distinctive rhythmic squeak, and a shadowy head the window.  Keys jingle.  The door opens, and Lowell tur lights.  He approaches the waste basket and slides it out
FROM OVERHEAD - JIM circles the track. ON THE GROUND -- JIM does pushups. Then sit-ups.
The next day held the promise of a new  beginning. After all, what harm had  really been done? No one was dead.
Now all clean and refreshed and whistling a merry tune, J check his box, giving a wave to Miss Seeder.
Hi, Linda.
JIM continues to whistle as he looks through his mail.
Life would go on, and I would certainly  be a stronger and wiser person from the  experience.
Uh, Jim?
Hmm?
Walt needs to see you.
Oh.  Okay.
Still absorbed in his papers, JIM heads over to Walt's do
You rang?

JIM stops cold. Walt is not alone. Barbara Flick and a bl Tracy are there. So are Larry Fouch, Ron Bell, and Lowell Prominently displayed on Walt's desk are TWO CRINKLED BAL takes an eternal few seconds to absorb what is happening.
Mr. McAllister, I hope you can help us  clear something up.
Look at his face!  He knows he's been  caught. Look at his face! (to Jim) Your ass is grass, Mister!
You said I was a liar   You're the  liar, you're the --
Larry, you just take it easy
All turn and stare at Jim. Come to think of it, he does l guilty.
MS. HOY leads the class in recitation. Paul responds alon companeros.
Yo --
pierdo.
Tu
pierdes.
El/ella -
pierde.
A STUDENT AIDE enters the classroom and hands a note to t who upon reading the note looks up at Paul
Senor presidente?
The class laughs fondly.  Paul looks around, beaming with embarrassment and pride.
Quieren verte en la oficina.
Huh?
Paul walks down the hall, a bounce in his step on this fi morning.
Senor presidente. Yo soy senor  presidente... El grande presidente...

I don't know why, but finding out there  was a mistake and I hadn't won the  election after all didn't bother me that  much. Winning had seemed kind of unreal  anyway. I guess I should have voted for  myself. Oh, well.
Paul reaches the -- INT. SCHOOL OFFICE        CONTINUOUS and enters Walt's of is there
(standing up) Take a seat, son. We've got something  hard to tell you.
Is Tammy okay?
She's okay. It's about the election.
Walt closes the door in our faces. We hold on the door.

After Paul got the bad news, Walt asked  for a few minutes alone with me. It was  very simple, really. I offered my  resignation, and he accepted. Very  quietly, it was all over for JIM  McAllister at Millard High - twelve  years of hard work down the drain.
The door opens revealing that only wait and JIM remain. T staff is hushed as JIM the Zombie Cyclops emerges into th walks somberly toward Miss Boeder. His voice quavers at h
Walt will be speaking with you about  this, but I need you to find someone to  take over my classes. The lesson plans  for the rest of the year are in my top  right drawer.
Okay, Jim. I understand.
Thanks. Well. I'm going home now.

As JIM moves toward the parking lot, the school recedes i PROJECTION that suggests he is floating. The MUSIC here r gravity of the moment, the inevitability of his fate. JIM stops walking, and a disembodied STEEPING WHEEL float hands. The scene behind changes to:
The city passing by outside is another strange REAR PROJE grips the floating steering wheel and makes turns wildly with the background.
I don't remember driving home, or much  of anything that happened in the next  few days.
JIM lets go of the steering wheel, and it drifts away. JI back to camera to face -
JIM drifts toward his house, and it absorbs him through t door.

We're no longer in rear-projection land: reality has caug Jim. As he walks across the room, he strips off his shirt socks, and finally pants. Left only in his underwear, he the house and out into the - EXT. MCALLISTER BACKYARD        DAY and flops down in the the sky.
There were news stories in the paper  and on television, former students  calling with their support, endless  hours of doing nothing, thinking  nothing.
A shadow falls over Jim's face, and a hand offers him a g tea. Grateful, JIM takes it, and looks up at - DIANE, her head blocking the sun.
Diane stood by me through the entire  humiliating ordeal, in a way, it sort of  evened things out between us.
Diane leaves. JIM looks up at the sky.

Soon school was over, and summer  stretched out in front of me as it  always had. Funny how the rhythm of the  school year remains ingrained in you for  life. in mid-June we found out Diane was  pregnant.
UNDER BLACK we hear the opening bars of a bouncy TIJUANA
twisting to the music at a PARTY, a giant grin on his  fa sombrero with tassels on his head. Behind him  we can see illuminated GRAVEL CONVEYOR. SUPER-IMPOSED:  "ONE YEAR LA

Senior year was great I Sure, I didn't  get to play ball or be president, but I  got elected homecoming king and prom  king anyway. I got into Nebraska like I  wanted and early-rushed Phi Delts. At  the end of the year me and my buddies  threw a hitching Mexican party down at  the cement plant. Shit, that was a good  party. That was a good party!
Paul is at a KEG, pumping it up and serving himself  a be a sip, seems to grow pensive.
The only really bad thing about senior  year was Lisa. Right before Christmas  she dumped me. One minute she's totally  in love with me and then boom she's  going out with my football buddy Randy.
Paul looks over at LISA dancing suggestively with RANDY Paul looks sad, takes another gulp, waves at unseen  frie
Sometimes I wonder what would've  happened if I'd actually won the  election.  Maybe my whole life would be  different.  Like I might never have gone  to Yosemite with Greg and Travis.
Paul takes a BIG GULP and looks into camera.
Or maybe I'd be dead.
UNDER BLACK we hear a distinctive AIRY HISS.
Tammy takes a big toke off a JOINT.
Catholic school was great!
Tammy and JENNIFER, a Sacred Heart schoolmate, are jammed bathroom stall.
I mean, the teachers kind of sucked,  and they were supposedly way more  strict, but you could get away with  murder.
Tammy hands off the doob to Jennifer, who takes a huge hi
The best thing about Sacred Heart was  meeting Jennifer.
Jennifer looks at Tammy.  Tammy looks at Jennifer
accompanied by the early '70's song, "Jennifer." SUPER-8 glimpses of Tammy and Jennifer in the Sacred Heart hallwa in the park, Jennifer dancing in Tammy's room, and finall SWINGING.
All those feelings I had for Lisa were  just preparing me for the real thing.   Jennifer and I are soul mates, and we're  never, ever, ever going to be apart.
we hear the MURMUR of a small crowd, interrupted by the B BANG of a GAVEL.
Senior year was very productive for me  and full of personal achievement.
Tracy officiates a MEETING.  Next to her at the head tabl Raynor and other council members.
Order.  Order.  Order I  Can we vote on  this?  Those in favor.
On top of a very successful student  council year, I got into Cornell like I  wanted, with scholarships, and I was in  the top 7th percentile of my graduating  class.
TRACY Approved
Tracy walks along the edge of a pond on this overcast day are crossed, and she wears an oversized woolen sweater. softly through her hair.
But sometimes I got lonely, and I'd  think about Dave.  I missed our talks.   Maybe it could have worked out between  us.  I don't know.
Wearing the red vest and "Ask me" button of a Real Valu f Dave stands above a case of SPRAY PAINT. He is stamping p every cap.
I wonder what he's doing now. Maybe he  finally finished his novel

It's ANNUAL distribution time, and crowd of excited stude up to get their precious book of memories. Many have alre theirs and are crowded around dining tables, gleefully ex mots. Tracy takes her annual and quickly opens it to the INDEX. CLOSE ON TRACT'S NAME - followed by a whopping list of pa
When the yearbooks came out, I was on  almost every page.

Tracy walks outside hugging her yearbook and sees PAUL AT HIS TRUCK, surrounded by supplicants. Tracy stops for a moment and watches.  She gathers her co heads toward him.  Paul doesn't even notice her, so occup with his friends and admirers.
Paul, will you sign my yearbook?
Sure, Tracy.
Paul takes the book, efficiently finds the page with his goes to work.
Can I sign yours too?
Oh, yeah, sure.  (to a friend) Hey Nolan, give my book to Tracy when  you're done*

Nolan finishes and hands the book over.  Tracy turns to t pages and finds them completely filled, as are the end pa looks for her picture.  When she finds it, it's almost co obscured by part of some ASSWIPE 'S long, illegible, excl point-filled message.  Finally, she locates an available begins to write.
I thought very carefully about what to  write.  Because despite everything that  had happened with the election, I really  wished him well.  I even signed it...
CLOSE ON - Tracy writing: "Love, Tracy" beneath her inscr Tracy takes Paul's book back to him.  He's already workin annual and barely looks up when he swaps with her.
Thanks, Tracy.
Tracy starts to walk away and Paul stops her
Hey, Tracy I..
She turns around expectantly
Yes, Paul?
Have a great summer.  And good luck at  college.
(genuinely moved) Thanks.  You too.  It was great working  with you.
Tracy opens the book as she walks and stops when she find AN ALMOST BLANK PAGE with Paul's puny inscription at the Have a great Summer!  Good luck at college   Paul Metzier
Tracy looks at herself in a mirror, as though dispassiona assessing her own face.  Then she begins to put on lipsti

After graduation, I don't know.  ;  somehow felt empty inside.  I guess high  school just seemed so meaningless now  and I couldn't wait to get out of Omaha.   Next year I was going to make all new  friends.  Smarter, more ambitious  friends.  It was time to move on. There  was nothing left for roe here.  I just  had one more thing to take care of.
UNDER BLACK comes the sound of a BUSY COMMERCIAL STREET.
After two months of sitting on my ass  and two months helping out at my  brother-in-law's travel agency...
A standard-issue car dealership: banner-draped lot, glass showroom.
...I landed a position at a Saturn  dealership.
All those cars and that new-car SMELL IN HIS CUBICLE JIM is typing at his desk across from a 55 CUSTOMER.
I never thought I'd end up selling  cars, but it's not so bad. I like the  Saturn philosophy -- it really is a  different kind of company.
A FRAMED SNAPSHOT on Jim's desk shows Diane and him with ONE.
I'm just relieved to have a steady  income now that there are three of us.
OUTSIDE ON THE LOT JIM saunters toward a client reading s INSIDE THE DEALERSHIP JIM explains features of a CROSS-SE
THE CLIENT IS IN A DRIVER'S SEAT while JIM leans in from window, pointing out dashboard features.
Actually, it wasn't so difficult making  the transition from teaching to selling.   It's like I tell my customers: my role  is just to educate people so they can  make informed decisions.
THE GLASS DOORS TO THE SHOWROOM OPEN, and JIM watches a s customer drive slowly away in a new Saturn Twin Cam.
When I send someone home with a new  unit, I feel a genuine sense of pride.

text: The room consists of mismatched sofas and chairs around a table.  There's a TV that no one watches. Sleeves rolled up and tie loosened, JIM eats a sandwich n OTHER SALESMEN and a FEMALE ACCOUNTANT who like him are e and watching TV.  NO one speaks.
So that's about it.  Maybe I'll get  back to teaching someday, but for the  time being, I guess I'm pretty happy  where I'm at.
A SALESMAN pokes his head in the door.
(to Jim) Hey, Professor.  There's a young gal  out here asking for you.
Oh
JIM chews quicker and wipes his mouth as he stands up, st tie.
(low, as JIM  passes) She's a real hot tamale.
JIM walks among the shiny new cars and sees the back of a young woman in a red dress and heels.  She turns around: JIM is truly surprised.
Hello, Mr. M.
Hello, Tracy.
JIM waits for Tracy to lead the way, but she doesn't
So what brings you here?
I'm looking at new cars.
Oh.  New cars.  I see.  Well, you came  to the right place
My mother's buying me a new car for  college.
Huh.  Right.  College.  Wow.  Where are  you going?  Where 'd you get into?
Well, I got in everywhere I applied,  but Cornell is my first choice.
Good for you.  Good for you
An uncomfortable pause.  JIM shifts gears.
So, are you looking for something  sporty or more practical?
Sporty.
A test drive. JIM is in the passenger seat. Tracy nears t dealership's driveway.
Where to?
Anywhere you want. (checks his watch) Just so long as we're not gone more  than a half-hour.
Tracy turns right.  They drive a moment in silence.
Handles pretty good, don't you think?
Yeah.
Plenty of pep, too.
Uh-huh.
And this model comes with ABS and dual  air bags standard.
That sounds good.
A silence
So Tracy?
Yes?
Why are you doing this?
Doing what?
Coming to see me.  Are you trying to. .  humiliate me?

Nooo.  I just thought...  l mean, I am  looking for a new car.  But I just  thought, well, I'm going away soon, and  you'll be stuck here and, I don't know,  I just think maybe if things had been  different we might have been, well,  friends. Real friends.  And then things  would be different.  Don't you think?
JIM just looks at Tracy - it's so very odd
Well, I... I... that's very nice of  you.
(excited)  I've got an idea.
Tracy suddenly signals and takes a right.
Tracy and JIM and the Saturn zoom by.
Tracy takes a corner and pulls to a stop in front of a mo class house.
What's this?
My house.
Tracy sets the parking brake.  Jim's eyes register a supp
I don't understand.  What's the deal?
Tracy looks deeply into Jim's eyes.
I want you to do something for me.
Swallows, unsure what heaven or hell  awaits him.
(getting out) I just have to get something. I'll be  right back.

Tracy heads toward the house. JIM sits and waits.  He sca house, notices the chipped and peeling paint,  the rustin furniture, the bowed porch steps. NOW TRACY opens the door and gets in. She carries her YEA gives it to Jim.
Oh, is this...?  (thumbing through  it) God. First one of these I haven't been  in for a long time.

What a surprise.
Take as much room as you want

You'll be fine.
I hope so
